awd_titl_txt: CHS: Small: Feedback-based Stroke Rehabilitation Using Multiple Simultaneous Therapies
awd_abstract_narration:
Walking is a fundamental daily activity, and independent walking is a primary goal for individuals with a stroke. However, less than 22% of people with a stroke are able to regain sufficient functional walking to be considered independent community ambulators. Many individuals with a stroke have asymmetric walking patterns (e.g., different step lengths with each leg) that reduce walking efficiency, decrease walking speed, and increase the likelihood of injuries and falls. To get a feel for asymmetric gait, one can try wearing a thick-soled heavy shoe on one foot and go barefoot on the other; then try to walk with the same step length on each foot while maintaining a consistent timing between placing each foot on the ground. This simple perturbation will likely modify the gait such that the person has to push harder with one leg during walking. In contrast to the one perturbation in this example, each of the millions of individuals with a stroke have multiple asymmetric changes that compound the detrimental effects. While there are many different therapies to help individuals regain their walking ability, disabilities are unique and often need a solution specific to each person. This project will use a combination of existing therapies applied simultaneously to generate a user-specific therapy that adapts to the individual's needs. This project focuses on gait rehabilitation after a stroke but may lead to benefits in therapies for gait recovery in individuals with lower limb amputations, hemiparetic cerebral palsy, and other gait impairments.

This project addresses research questions such as: (i) what is the level of the symmetry that can potentially be targeted for a patient that has inherent asymmetry in functionality; (ii) what factors influence the perception of a symmetric gait; (iii) how to model the interactions among multiple therapies used for rehabilitation. To answer these questions, the research team will first understand how the effects from two different therapies combine. Based on the results of multiple pairs of simultaneous therapies, the second phase will use real-time feedback, based on the measured gait to optimize the output from two or more individual therapies. Controlling multiple therapies should allow for the control of multiple gait parameters that can change the gait pattern in a user-specific way.  Since individuals with a stroke inherently have different force and motion capabilities on each leg, perfect symmetry may not be possible. Throughout this project, experiments will determine the bounds of acceptable asymmetry from a visual perspective. This perception will help understand what clinical physical therapists perceive about gait and help direct their attention to important parameters, particularly those that both have a large impact on gait function but are not easily perceived. Although the resulting gait may have some degree of asymmetry in all measures, the gait pattern will likely be less visually noticeable and meet the functional walking goals of individuals with asymmetric impairments.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
This research focused on finding ways to help individuals with asymmetric impairments, such as from a stroke, relearn walking patterns that are both functional and natural in appearance. By integrating multiple rehabilitation methods — such as treadmill training with different speeds for each foot and asymmetric rhythmic cues — we sought to improve a broad range of gait parameters simultaneously.

Intellectual Merits:

Through this research, we developed a deeper understanding for the ways different therapeutic approaches complement each other in practice. When multiple interventions are used together, they can generate overall improved gait patterns, even if each individual therapy becomes slightly less effective. We found this trade-off to be beneficial: the combination of therapies produced improvements across multiple aspects of walking that would not be as effective if each therapy were used on its own. These findings show how combining therapies, when done thoughtfully, can lead to more extensive improvements, which benefits the clinicians who implement these strategies and, most importantly, the individuals striving to walk with greater stability and confidence.

We also created new mathematical models and experimental methods to examine how different therapies interact. These models revealed how the body and brain adapt to each intervention, showing that each therapy focuses on specific gait features (like step length, timing, or force). Our work on asymmetric gait patterns may also inform the design of advanced prosthetics, exoskeletons, and robotic assistive devices. By simulating and predicting how the human body responds to various interventions, engineers and therapists can create tailored equipment that seamlessly integrates with each person’s unique walking pattern. This approach could boost the use of assistive technologies in rehabilitation, ultimately helping individuals regain greater independence and mobility.

In addition, we incorporated real-time feedback so that each participant’s unique needs were addressed during training. This approach allowed us to fine-tune treadmill speeds or auditory cues on the fly, guiding each person toward a more balanced and steady gait. Moreover, examining how people perceive and judge these modified gaits highlighted the need to consider not only objective measurements, but also subjective impressions of walking quality.

Broader Impacts:

By enhancing our understanding of how multiple rehabilitation methods can be combined effectively, this research could improve clinical practices for individuals recovering from stroke or other mobility-limiting conditions. Clinicians can draw on our findings to design personalized treatment plans that, for example, coordinate treadmill therapy and rhythmic cueing to address multiple gait elements (such as spatial and temporal parameters) simultaneously. This could lead to shorter recovery times and better overall quality of life.

Beyond the core research, we also focused on educational outreach. We offered demonstrations to middle and high school students, showcasing our real-time gait measurement systems and explaining fundamental concepts in rehabilitation engineering. Some of these students participated in short-term lab projects, gaining direct experience in data collection and analysis. Several graduate students received dedicated guidance and professional mentorship, strengthening their research skills and academic development. Several undergraduate students were also involved, learning about research by assisting with experiments and data interpretation. These demonstrations and hands-on activities spurred excitement among younger learners and helped foster a new generation of scientists and engineers who appreciate the transformative power of rehabilitation research to improve lives.


Last Modified: 01/10/2025
Modified by: Kyle B Reed
